meaning_mnemonic: You <radical>say</radical> stuff to a <radical>river</radical>, giving it <kanji>instruction</kanji>. This river is a new river so it needs you to say things, giving it instruction on what to do. Otherwise the river wouldn’t know how to behave.
reading_mnemonic: While giving <kanji>instruction</kanji> to the river, you see a small boat coming down it. Inside the miniature boat is a rac<reading>coon</reading> (くん) captain and his raccoon crew. The raccoon captain is instructing them, “Stroke! Stroke!”

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>bow</radical> radical and the <kanji>bow</kanji> kanji are exactly the same!
reading_mnemonic: You have a <kanji>bow</kanji> in one hand and in the other... a <reading>cu</reading>cumber (きゅう). You're going to shoot this cucumber with this bow into the salad you're making. Many people don't know this, but this makes your cucumbers taste better.

meaning_mnemonic: Saying you're going to <radical>slide</radical> the <radical>dirt</radical> out of your <radical>mouth</radical> is just another way of saying you're going to <kanji>announce</kanji> something. All that information is the dirt, and to announce that dirt you just slide it on out of your mouth. How's that for a visual?
reading_mnemonic: Now that you're about to <kanji>announce</kanji> something important, you should maybe get it nice and smooth in your mouth so the dirt can slide out easier. So take a big gulp of <reading>Coke</reading> (こく). Coke is just like, the dirt of soda anyway, you know?

meaning_mnemonic: If a <radical>grain</radical> seems extra <radical>heavy</radical>, you know it's a different <kanji>kind</kanji>. Not all <kanji>type</kanji>s of grains are the same. So when you feel the heavy type, you know it isn't the same as the light kind.
reading_mnemonic: You sort all of the different <kanji>kind</kanji>s and <kanji>type</kanji>s by putting them in the right <reading>chu</reading>tes (しゅ). They slide away, probably to some big type-based piles you can't see.

meaning_mnemonic: You ride your scooter through the dirt while carrying a sheep because you're determined to attain something. Greatness? Glory? Everlasting fame? Maybe you'll attain a plural combination of all those things. After all, you are the best sheep-carrying off-road scooterist the world has ever seen.
reading_mnemonic: After you <kanji>attain</kanji> that <kanji>plural</kanji> combination of glory, greatness, and fame, you get a <reading>tattoo</reading> (たつ) to celebrate: "world's greatest," in gothic lettering, above a picture of you and your sheep on your scooter.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>rice</radical> you feed to a <radical>big</radical> <radical>geoduck</radical> can be of any <kanji>type</kanji>, <kanji>kind</kanji>, or <kanji>category</kanji>. It doesn't matter what kind of rice it is, the big geoduck will eat it.
reading_mnemonic: While eating every <kanji>type</kanji> and <kanji>kind</kanji> of rice from every <kanji>category</kanji>, the big geoduck has become even bigger. Its body is <reading>rui</reading>ned (るい). It's painfully obese. This geoduck has eaten itself to ruin.

meaning_mnemonic: You want to share <radical>happiness</radical> with people so you <radical>stamp</radical> <radical>stool</radical>s with the <kanji>news</kanji>. Now when people want a <kanji>report</kanji> of all the happy things going on, they can just look down before they sit.
reading_mnemonic: You research and <kanji>report</kanji> the <kanji>news</kanji> from <reading>ho</reading>me (ほう). Only after, once all of the news is stamped onto the stools, do you leave your home.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>bamboo</radical> <radical>temple</radical> is <kanji>equal</kanji> to all of the other non-bamboo temples. Just because it's made of bamboo doesn't make it any less special and spiritual.
reading_mnemonic: The bamboo temple is also an <kanji>equal</kanji> distance away from the other temples in <reading>とう</reading>きょう. When you look at a map of とうきょう temples, you can measure them out and they'll all be perfectly equal.

meaning_mnemonic: The water from a <radical>tsunami</radical> can create a lot of <radical>energy</radical> when made into <kanji>steam</kanji>. Steam power used to be all the rage back in the day. Steam comes from water, water comes from tsunamis, so logically, tsunamis are a great source of energy.
reading_mnemonic: In order to contain this <kanji>steam</kanji> energy and store it for later, you lock it up in a box with a <reading>key</reading> (き). That way the energy can be used at a later time. Provided you don’t lose the key, that is.

meaning_mnemonic: Your <radical>leader</radical> from <radical>long ago</radical> thought to <kanji>borrow</kanji> something precious from you. This leader did not return the thing he borrowed, and now he will pay.
reading_mnemonic: In your rage, you decide to find this leader, take back what's yours, and in return, <kanji>borrow</kanji> the leader's life. So you found him, grabbed him, and threw him into a <reading>shack</reading> (しゃく) — where you "borrow" a few parts of the leader himself, and do other terrible things to him.

meaning_mnemonic:
In a dangerous <radical>fire</radical>, a <radical>gambler</radical> will always try to <kanji>bake</kanji> something before fleeing to safety. It could be his own house on fire, and the gambler would still use the free heat source to get some baking done. Maybe he's gambling that those baked goods will offset the cost of a new home…

This kanji also means <kanji>burn</kanji>, because that's what happens when you expose something to a lot of heat.
reading_mnemonic: He used to <kanji>bake</kanji> for the <reading>Ya</reading>nkees (や). Baseball cakes, bat baguettes, that kind of thing. A career-ending kitchen injury forced him to retire. That's when he developed a gambling problem. But he still likes to bake whenever the Yankees are on TV.

meaning_mnemonic: Under a <radical>canopy</radical>, there are two <radical>person</radical>s on the <radical>dirt</radical>. What do they do there? They <kanji>sit</kanji>. The people use the dirt under the canopy as a <kanji>seat</kanji> for their butts.
reading_mnemonic: Who decided people have to <kanji>sit</kanji> like this? The C<reading>za</reading>r (ざ). The Czar wants to be above everyone, so he makes them sit on the dirt under canopies while he goes around on horseback or something, towering over them as they sit.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>death</radical> of your <radical>heart</radical> will cause you to <kanji>forget</kanji> all of the most important things. People think memories are kept in your brain, but that's not true. Your heart is where all of your most precious memories are kept, and when it dies, you forget them all.
reading_mnemonic: When someone <kanji>forget</kanji>s everything they're left with only one thing to do: go <reading>bow</reading>ling (ぼう). Bowling is easy, and there's nothing to forget. You pick up a ball. You drop it. Everything else is automatically taken care of.

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>tsunami</radical> <radical>previous</radical>ly gave everything in this town a good <kanji>wash</kanji>. There are many laundromats in this town, so when the previous tsunami hit, all of the detergent mixed with the water and gave everything a good wash.
reading_mnemonic: It wasn't just the town that got a <kanji>wash</kanji>, it was the <reading>cen</reading>taurs (せん) too. (Centaurs happen to live in this town.) And being half horse, centaurs have a lot of hair that needs washing. Luckily, the soap tsunami gave them a good wash too.

meaning_mnemonic: In a <radical>moon</radical> <radical>prison</radical>, there lies a <radical>treasure chest</radical> containing a golden <kanji>chest</kanji> piece. This mighty chest armor will grant you protection from nearly any attack, because it is imbued with moon magic.
reading_mnemonic: Where is this <kanji>chest</kanji> armor from? It's from the moon. Now how would you say that if you were Canadian? It's from the <reading>moon, eh</reading> (むね). Right, this here chest armor is from the moon, eh.

meaning_mnemonic: Nestled in the light of the <radical>moon</radical> in the <radical>grass</radical> is a <radical>treasure chest</radical> that you can see with your <kanji>brain</kanji>. You close your eyes, and you can see the spot, but it's kept deep in your brain, and you have to use its power to find it.
reading_mnemonic: If you can unlock the secrets of your <kanji>brain</kanji> you'll have powers like <reading>No</reading>stradamus (のう). Nostradamus was able to look inward at his own hidden brain treasure chest and see the future, so maybe you can be like him too.

meaning_mnemonic: A religious <radical>leader</radical> wearing a <radical>mask</radical> could be either a <kanji>monk</kanji> or a <kanji>priest</kanji>. You don’t know, their face is covered by a mask!
reading_mnemonic: This <kanji>monk</kanji> or <kanji>priest</kanji> is wearing a mask to protect their <reading>sou</reading>l (そう). You aren't a monk or a priest, so they don't want your not-religious-enough eyes to dirty their soul.

meaning_mnemonic: You want your <radical>spirit</radical> to be <radical>simple</radical> so you practice <kanji>Zen Buddhism</kanji>. Zen is all about meditating and letting earthly things go. There's nothing more simple for your spirit than being <kanji>Zen</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading for this kanji is <reading>Zen</reading> (ぜん), just like the <kanji>Zen</kanji> in <kanji>Zen Buddhism</kanji>. Pretty easy to remember, no? Just remember that the reading is the same as the meaning. It’s easy!

meaning_mnemonic: With a <radical>lip ring</radical>, anything is <kanji>possible</kanji>. Having a lip ring grants you the power to conquer any obstacle, achieve any goal. As long as it's a <kanji>passable</kanji> lip ring, that is. If it isn't good enough, it isn't possible to be passable.
reading_mnemonic: Since anything and everything is <kanji>possible</kanji> with your new <kanji>passable</kanji> lip ring, you use it to get a new <reading>ca</reading>r (か). You go to the car dealership and ask for a free (passable) car. The manager is impressed with your lip ring and gladly hands over the keys to the latest model of your favorite car. Not bad.

meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Say</radical> it at <radical>noon</radical>. That's the only time I will <kanji>allow</kanji> you to say it. That's the only time I will <kanji>permit</kanji> you to say it. Other than that, no saying anything. Noon is your window.
reading_mnemonic: Where do these archaic horrible rules exist? The smaller version of Kyoto, Little <reading>Kyo</reading>to (きょ). Normal Kyoto is just fine. This smaller one is where a group of people went to create their own little town with their own dumb rules.

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>tree</radical> that's been sliced up in <radical>winter</radical> can be used as a <kanji>flat object counter</kanji>. Since it's winter, all the leaves have fallen off the tree, so it's easy to cut into slats. These slats can be used as counters for flat objects.
reading_mnemonic: As you count each <kanji>counter for flat objects</kanji>, a bunch of <reading>mi</reading>ce (まい) show up and start climbing all over you. This won't do, so you take two slats and start smashing and flattening all the mice. Now that the mice are flat too, you can also use them as a counter for flat objects. Good job, mice.

meaning_mnemonic: Within the <radical>blue</radical> water, a <radical>conflict</radical> stirs, but is made <kanji>quiet</kanji> by the muffling power of liquid. Under this blue water is a great conflict between two sea monsters, but on the surface it appears peaceful and quiet as the water prevents sound from rising above the surface.
reading_mnemonic: As you watch below the <kanji>quiet</kanji> water, every once in a while a <reading>sa</reading>ber (せい) breaches the surface and quietly slices back down.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>paragraph</radical> radical and the <kanji>paragraph</kanji> kanji are exactly the same!
reading_mnemonic: You have to write an entire <kanji>paragraph</kanji> about a topic, so you choose <reading>coo</reading>kies (く).

meaning_mnemonic: Killing two <radical>tree</radical>s with a <radical>jackhammer</radical> is expressly <kanji>prohibit</kanji>ed. Don't get me wrong, you can rip up one tree with your jackhammer, but not two.
reading_mnemonic: The person who decided to <kanji>prohibit</kanji> jackhammering two trees is the <reading>Kin</reading>g (きん) of England. He's the only person who's able to prohibit certain things, so it had to be him.

meaning_mnemonic: In your <radical>mouth</radical> you put your <radical>life</radical> on the line by putting in a <radical>sword</radical> that is <radical>big</radical>. You put it all the way down there, so you <kanji>consume</kanji> it.
reading_mnemonic: The "<kanji>consume</kanji> a sword" illusion came with a cheap magic <reading>kit</reading> (きつ) you had.

meaning_mnemonic: If you have a <radical>fire</radical> and a <radical>helicopter</radical> hovering beside it, there's going to be a lot of <radical>dirt</radical> and <kanji>smoke</kanji> billowing around. Mostly smoke, on account of the fire. Now it's in your eyes and mouth. It gets in your lungs and you can't breathe. Why, helicopter, why!
reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>smoke</kanji> is too much and you realize this is the <reading>en</reading>d (えん) for you. You're gonna die here!

meaning_mnemonic: Into your <radical>mouth</radical> the <radical>leader</radical> shot an <radical>arrow</radical> with an attached <radical>hook</radical> so that they'd be able to see into your <kanji>throat</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: From your <kanji>throat</kanji> you hear a voice. Not yours, but one you recognize. It's <reading>こう</reading>いち! What's that rascal doing down in your throat?

meaning_mnemonic: On your <radical>mouth</radical> is a <radical>stamp</radical> that you <kanji>tap</kanji>, <kanji>strike</kanji> and <kanji>slap</kanji> to create a beat! The stamp looks like a little drum, but you're really just hitting your mouth for fun (the stamp was an excuse to make it seem normal).
reading_mnemonic: When you <kanji>tap</kanji> and <kanji>strike</kanji> the stamp on your mouth, you make a <reading>ta-ta</reading> (たた) sound. Imagine yourself making a beat with the little stamp drum on your mouth. Now listen... たた! There! Did you hear it?

meaning_mnemonic: What do you <radical>eat</radical> like a <radical>machine</radical>? <kanji>Candy</kanji>!
reading_mnemonic: This <kanji>candy</kanji> in particular is just drops of hardened, clear sugar that looks like <reading>雨</reading> (あめ) drops.

meaning_mnemonic: Using <radical>flowers</radical> to make a <radical>lip ring</radical> is always going to end in <kanji>frustration</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: After some <kanji>frustration</kanji>, you made your flower lip ring. Now you look like an <reading>Egy</reading>ptian  (いじ) pharaoh. Because all ancient Egyptian monarchs wore flower lip rings (historical fact)!

meaning_mnemonic: You've got a <radical>car</radical>, a <radical>weapon</radical>, and some <radical>thread</radical> lying around. So of course you decide to <kanji>connect</kanji> them all together.
reading_mnemonic: There's only one reason you've <kanji>connected</kanji> all this together: <reading>Tuna</reading> (つな) fishing. Obviously!
